makers.displaydate: 1928–1987; born Pittsburgh, PA; died New York, NY; active New York
makers.displaymaker: Andy Warhol, 1928–1987; born Pittsburgh, PA; died New York, NY; active New York

texts.textentryhtml: During the Cultural Revolution of 1966–76, Mao Zedong, the leader of China’s Communist Party and founder of the People’s Republic of China, mandated the display of his official portrait throughout the country, creating just the kind of larger-than-life identity that drew Warhol to celebrity subjects such as Marilyn Monroe and Elvis Presley. The opening of diplomatic relations between the United States and China in the early 1970s attracted widespread media attention, and the state portrait of Mao (based on which Warhol made these screenprints) represented not merely the man but the entire nation and culture to an international audience. Warhol created many interpretations of Mao, as silkscreens on canvas as well as screenprints on paper, using the techniques of mass-reproduced imagery to echo the ubiquity of Mao’s image in the cultural politics of the era.

bibliography.boilertext: Johanna Burton et al., Pop art: contemporary perspectives, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum; New Haven, CT: distributed by Yale University Press, 2007)
